BGR recommends ousting elected officials from Sewerage & Water Board
<time aria-label=""Article Published Date and Time"" class=""dateline__published"" datetime=""2011-10-25T13:20"" id=""dateline__published"">Posted on October 25, 2011 at  1:20 PM</time>
By Martha Carr, Nola.com

In order to restore confidence and persuade New Orleans residents to support future rate increases, a local watchdog group is proposing a slate of reforms aimed at depoliticizing and professionalizing the Sewerage & Water Board, including granting the agency limited power to raise rates without City Council approval. The report issued Tuesday by the Bureau of Governmental Research is the first of two reports by good-government groups on the S&WB expected in the coming weeks.

John McCusker / The Times-PicayuneJohn McCusker/The Times-Picayune Mayor Mitch Landrieu and Sewage and Water Board executiv director Marcia St. Martin walk through Drainage Pump Station #1 Wednesday, February 9, 2011. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the Sewage and Water Board marked the completion of the $39.6 million federal pump station and repair program in Orleans parish.

The Business Council of New Orleans and the River Region will also make recommendations on how the water board should be governed as part of a request this year by Mayor Mitch Landrieu for an outside review of the agency's finances and management.

BGR's report recommends removing the mayor and three City Council members from the water board, which would reduce its size from 13 to nine members. It also recommends reducing board members' terms from nine years to four, and limiting members to three consecutive terms in office. Currently there are no term limits, allowing some long-serving members to gain substantial political power, the report states.

The watchdog group also would like to see the Legislature pass a law requiring that seven of the nine members have extensive professional experience in finance, accounting, business administration, engineering, law, information technology or public health.

The Business Council attempted to get a law passed in 2008 professionalizing the citizen members of the board, hoping to remove a perception of cronyism that might threaten the flow of federal money for drainage improvements. The board skewered the proposal, and it failed to get out of committee when it was taken up by the Legislature. The Business Council propelled campaigns to consolidate levee boards and merge the city's seven property assessors into one office.
""We were roasted like hot dogs,"" said Bob Brown, the council's managing director. ""That's one reason we decide to come back to it.""

Chronically underfunded due to political pressure to keep rates low, the water board suffers from widespread water leaks, a sewer system that is still under federal consent decree, and an aging power plant that has suffered two major outages since Hurricane Katrina, one of which prompted a boil-water order.
To deal with the problem, a consultant has recently mapped out a 10-year, $3.5 billion capital program that would be funded in part by $1 billion in possible tax, rate and fee increases.
But the agency has along way to go in increasing the public's trust, the report states.

-- Give the water board limited authority to raise water and sewer rates, as well as drainage fees, by reasonable amounts. The increases would be tied to an annual index or other measure. For larger increases, the board would still have to get City Council approval.

-- Consolidate all drainage functions under the water board. Currently the water board is responsible for pipes 36 inches or larger, drainage canals and pump stations. The rest of the drainage system, including more than 85,000 catch basins and 1,600 miles of smaller-diameter drainage pipes, is managed by the city's Department of Public Works.
-- Reduce the board's role in approving contracts.
-- Institute an annual review of the water board's top administrators, including executive director Marcia St. Martin.

The Urbana Board of Aldermen discussed that city's voluntary
boil order at its regular meeting Wednesday, Oct. 12, which is
still in effect until specimen sample results come back from the

Department of Natural Resources.

Mayor Travis Martin said the boil order is a recommended procedure
and precautionary measure to ensure water quality after the city
had to shut water off, dropping water pressure in the city below 20
pounds of pressure on Tuesday, Oct. 11. This is because the city
encountered a technical problem while tapping a main for a new

service hookup, Martin said.

The city expects to hear results from DNR within the next few
In other business, the board heard from city attorney Mel Gilbert,
who offered some considerations to the aldermen as they approach
refining their chain of command policy. Martin offered to draft the

new policy if the board wanted one.

""It's just a matter of getting it in black and white so everything
can be consistent,"" Gilbert said, adding that not all cities find a

chain of command policy necessary.

Alderman Steve Dyson asked Gilbert about the board's hiring and
firing process, and Gilbert clarified that the mayor could not
terminate a position alone. He said in his opinion, all a mayor
could do is suspend an employee without pay.
Gilbert also discussed several other items with the aldermen,
including policies for evidence disposal, pending litigation,
contracts and bid taking, court dates and consultation with the

city attorney.

The board also heard from Cassie VanMiddlesworth, who is heading up
the city's Halloween activities and Christmas parade.
VanMiddlesworth said she and other volunteers are looking at having
the parade at 3 p.m. Saturday, Dec. 10, with judging at 2:30 p.m.
and judging for royalty at noon. She said after the parade, she
hopes to have a meet-and-greet with Santa Claus. Volunteers are
considering a tentative theme for this year's parade, which would

be ""A Country Christmas.""

Halloween activities at the city park are still planned as before,
from 4 to 7 p.m. with children's activities including a costume
contest, trunk or treating, games and other activities.

Other business conducted by the board includes the following:

• The board voted unanimously in closed session to give a raise to

city maintenance worker Donnie Jones, from $9 to $10 an hour.

• Martin suggested looking into the grant stipulations surrounding
the purchase of the city's police motorcycle, which was damaged
after accidentally being tipped over and needs repaired. Dyson had
suggested selling the motorcycle, but Martin explained before the
city can move forward with a decision, the board needs to ensure it
follows requirements as stated in the grant.
• The board unanimously voted to pay for maintenance supervisor
Ryan Mitchell to attend a wastewater symposium this month at Lake

of the Ozarks.

• Dyson suggested the city seek a part-time staffer to be available
on an as-needed basis to fill in at City Hall when or if city clerk
Candy VanMiddlesworth is unavailable. Gilbert suggested the board

post flyers for the position.

Park residents told to boil water

column5:
Thursday October 20, 2011

BENNINGTON -- Town officials have issued an emergency health order to residents of the Sunset Mobile Home Park requiring them to boil their water because of contamination.

column1: Bennington Town Manager Stuart A. Hurd said testing of the private well system, owned by John Bushee Jr., recently tested positive for E. coli. The park has had previous issues with the well, he said.
""It's been a problem for a number of years there. It's an older mobile home park with an older system,"" Hurd said. ""We've asked the owner to be more cognizant of the well.""
Bushee has been ordered to ""shock"" the system and then clear it for three days.

Bennington Health Officer Kevin Goodhue said a total of 11 notices have gone out to residents of the park located at the top of Harwood Hill. The notices inform residents that water should not be used for drinking or cooking unless it is boiled for at least one minute, Goodhue said.
Bushee has a right to appeal the order and will at a Select Board meeting on Monday, according to Goodhue. The board will determine following a hearing if the health order should continue.

Hornersville discusses water boil, fire department grant

Hornersville Mayor William Foresythe discusses issues facing the city. (File photo)

HORNERSVILLE, Mo. -- The Hornersville Board of Aldermen met on Tuesday evening and discussed the recent boil water order that the city has been under since a water main broke on Monday afternoon.

According to Elisa Johnson, city clerk, a utility company was doing some work in the city when workers accidentally hit a line causing a major water leak. Since then she says that the line has been repaired but residents are still cautioned to boil water before drinking. She notes that this is only a precautionary measure but when something like this happens, a boil water order is usually issued.
As to when the order will be lifted, she said that the city will have to take water samples and send them off for testing. When this is done, and they are declared safe, the order will be lifted

The city's Fire Department will also be a recipient of the Regional Communication Grant that some of the smaller communities have been asked to participate in. With the money from this grant, the city will be able to purchase some radios and pagers. Fire Chief Tommy Burgess has requested funds from the city, the American Legion, Farmers and Merchants Bank as well as the Fire Department itself to raise $1,761 which is the city's match for this grant. Burgess reported that the department has already received the American Legion portion of the grant which totals $450. Each organization has agreed upon this amount for its contribution.
Mayor William Foresythe added that the city hall is in need of a base radio in the case of an emergency.

Briefly discussed at Tuesday's meeting was a complaint that was filed by former Police officer Richard Lyell, now a volunteer fireman with the city's fire department. According to alderman, there was a question as to whether the complaint was just a complaint or actually a lawsuit. The city's insurance company, Moperm, had sent a letter to the city regarding this issue and referred to it as a lawsuit.

At last month's meeting, all alderman voted their approval and passed an ordinance that would prevent any person having a grievance against the city, lawsuit or not in good standing, to be employed by the city or any volunteer department. However, the city has learned from City Attorney Terry McVey, that this is not possible. McVey did tell city officials that if the individuals have drug charges against them, they can be dismissed from the volunteer departments until the case is settled.

In the Fire Department report, Burgess, noted that the department had voted on giving Keith Cole, Hornersville resident, $200 more for advertising the city's ""The Haunted."" Burgess told alderman that he expects donations for the event to offset this cost. He also made a request of the Police Department to spend more time patrolling the attraction in case there were any problems.

There was also a brief discussion with Burgess about how fire department members are voted on. There was a motion made by Alderman Billy Wyrick and seconded by Alderman Chris Coleman to have the board approve any new reserve or full-time volunteers in the future. Burgess was in agreement with the board.

Presenting the Police report in the absence of Police Chief John Nunnery was Alderman Wyrick. He told board members that Nunnery would be returning to work on Oct. 24. He has been out due to illness. Wyrick also informed the board that Police officer Daniel Kinder had given his two-week notice of resignation. Alderman Wyrick made a motion to accept the resignation and it was seconded by Alderman Coleman.
The motion carried four to zero. The department also responded to 54 calls in the city for the month of September.

In the water and sewer department, it was reported that progress has been made regarding sewer repairs. Some lines in the problem areas will have to be plugged, to allow the area to be pumped and dried out before excavation can begin.
Other issues brought before the board for discussion were the following:
* The city has made a decision to consult McVey concerning the number of liquor licenses that the city can approve;

* Mayor Foresythe informed alderman that whenever the city again receives FEMA funds, more repairs will be done on the streets. He added that the city had received $6,187.10 in FEMA funds for the fuel that was spent on running the pumps during the April flood;

* Foresythe reminded the Police Department to issue citations to individuals owning dogs that are not in compliance with the ordinances concerning dogs running loose and the keeping of vicious dogs in the city. These ordinances can be reviewed at City Hall by anyone wishing to do so.

At last month's meeting in closed session, alderman discussed a letter received by Officer Robert Blankenship. He had been approached concerning the possibility of becoming assistant to Nunnery, who has been out due to illness. However, this issue was tabled to when funding becomes available. When this occurs, it will be discussed at a future meeting. Council members agreed to contact the Dunklin County Sheriff's office to check the possibility of the city getting extra patrol when needed.
The next city council meeting will be at 6 p.m., on Nov. 15, 2011.
